For an element $a \in M$ of a monoid and an exponent $n \in \mathbb{N}$, the $n$th power of $a$, denoted $a^n$, is defined in the usual way. Note that $a^0 = e$, following the convention on empty products.
A group $G$ is called cyclic if it is generated by a single element. This is equivalent to the existence of a surjective group homomorphism $\mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow G$.

The degree of a polynomial f=
sum a_i X^i in R[X], denoted by deg f, is defined as the maximum i such that a_i 
eq 0. The degree is assigned -
infty for the zero polynomial.
A ring $R$ is called a principal ideal domain if it is an integral domain and every ideal of $R$ is principal.
An endomorphism of a ring $R$ is a homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R$.
A polynomial $f$ in a ring $R[X]$ is irreducible if it cannot be factored into the product of two non-constant polynomials in $R[X]$.

The minimal polynomial of an element \\(\alpha\\) in a field extension is the monic polynomial of lowest degree in the base field that has \\(\alpha\\) as a root. It is a prime polynomial and generates the kernel of the evaluation homomorphism from the polynomial ring of the base field to the field generated by \\(\alpha\\). 
(Alt.2)
Let $K \subset L$ be a field extension and $\alpha \in L$ an element that is algebraic over $K$. The unique monic polynomial $f \in K[X]$ of smallest degree such that $f(\alpha)=0$ is called the minimal polynomial of $\alpha$ over $K$.

A field $K$ is called algebraically closed if every nonconstant polynomial $f$ of $K[X]$ admits a zero in $K$, or in other words, if $f$ decomposes in $K[X]$ into a product of linear factors. This means that $f$ admits a product decomposition $f=c \prod_{i}\left(X-\alpha_{i}\right)$ with a constant $c \in K^{*}$ as well as zeros $\alpha_{i} \in K$.
An algebraic closure of a field $K$, denoted as $\bar{K}$, is an algebraically closed field that is algebraic over $K$.
An extension $L / K$ is called separable if it does not contain any inseparable algebraic elements over $K$.

The alternating group on $\{1, \ldots, n\}$, denoted as $\mathfrak{A}_{n}$, is the set of all even permutations in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, i.e., those permutations for which $\operatorname{sgn} \pi = 1$. It forms a normal subgroup of index 2 in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$.
The image of a function \( f: A 	o B \) is the set of all elements in \( B \) that have at least one corresponding element in \( A \) via the function \( f \).
